text: Tap. Pours slightly hazy orange, medium off white head, dissipates fairly slowly, good lacing. Aroma is malty, a bit dusty, caramel, rye bread, spicy, pine needles. Flavor is light sweet, light plus bitter, rye spicy, malty with a pine hop bite. Light plus body. Not bad.

Draft at Pi Pizzeria, Bethesda, MD on 10/07/16.  Arrived at the table a slightly hazy rust color with a skim of a beige head.  The smell was a little stale with some wet cardboard, orange juice, caramel, and a bit of a graininess.  Went down thin to medium-bodied.  Tasted like it smelled - stale/skunky and watered-down.  Some caramel and sweet grains were present upfront.  There was a little orange juice and some zesty citrus rinds at the end.  Completely forgettable.

On tap at the source, the Tap Room.  Pours a clear deep golden with a thin white head that mostly stays and rings the glass. Aroma is grassy. Taste is sweet caramel malt, lightly toasted bread, and a crisp character more reminiscent of a pilsner. Good example of the style.
Draft at Pi Cincinnati. Copper pour; biscuit, caramel, toast; pronounced malt presence, lightly sweet, moderate bitterness. Light body, average carbonation. Easy drinking, nice beer.
On tap at Pi Pizzeria. Nice orange body with big head. Nose is hoppy, toasty. Taste is malts, caramel, skunky. Hops in there galore. Bitter in the finish.

Draft. Poured clear golden color with an average frothy white head that lasted with good lacing. Moderate hop and sweet malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable beer.

Tap at pi
Pours a copper hue with a very small soapy white head and sparse lacing. Nose is toasted malt lite spicy hops a little mineral note. Flavors are fantastic toasted lite toffee malt with a nice spicy hops presence. Very solid for this style.
Light citrus and very easy to drinking. Pours amber with ok head and lacing. Light crisp finish. Tap at churchkey.
Not really my favorite beer. Has a bit of a funky taste that is a little off putting.

16 ounce draft pour at District of Pi Pizzeria in DC, nonic pint glass. Semi-clear golden brown with off-white head. Aromas of sweet malt, wheat. Tastes of sweet malt, caramel, light citrus, light wheat. Medium-light body with a dry finish. Medium carbonation. Decent, goes well enough with pizza.

On tap @ Pi Pizzeria. Clear orange colored beer with a tall white head. Aroma is big on pale malt, bread, and toast. Some caramel, a light orange hop aroma, flowers, and grass. Subtle pine. Flavor is malt forward and sweet. Lots of caramel, toast, and biscuit. Good floral hops, some orange peel, and mild bitterness. A bit of an estery quality on the finish. Mildly grassy.
Sample at Kansas Craft Brewers Expo. Comes a clear golden orange with a nice beige head. Aroma of malt, grain, and fruit. Taste is malt, grain, citrus, and floral. Crisp and dry. Easy to take.

Pint at Bottleworks. Clear and coppery with an off white head that leaves some lacing. This is nicely hopped with European hops. Some spiciness. Also floral and fruit. The hop notes ste mot huge but sre nicely complex. Malts are well balanced. Some biscuits. This is well hopped for the style and I approve.
Draft->shaker. Amber with medium white head. Great balance of caramel and toffee malt with hops and grains. Very drinkable.

On draft at Pi in Kirkwood. It poured a copper color with a small white head. The aroma was of caramel malts, some floral hops and a hint of nuts. The taste was of bread, toasted malts, yeast and hops. It was light bodied with medium carbonation. Tasty.

Location/Date:Draft on 6/20/2013 at District of Pi.
Appearance: Pours a caramel reddish orange. 
Aroma: Aroma of light toffee.
Taste: Light bitter, light toffee malt.
Palate:Light body.
Summary: Of course when Im out at lunch and am told to order a beer, I find the rarest one I can find as Im the 19th rater of this on RB. A very solid beer, not too aggressive to any one direction.

Poured a copper color with a white head.  Aroma is malty with some dry hops.  Taste is not as much like a common as I expected, but good malty flavors.  Some nice dry hops in the finish make it crispy.  Good.

Tap - fair size foamy head, nice medium copper color, nice balanced aroma and flavor, caramel malt, moderate earthy hop balance, very good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at Pi Pizzeria. Pours a golden orange color with white head. Malty, toast, slight bitter flavors. Good California Common.

Tap @ Pi STL. Pours a hazy dark orange appearance with a creamy, khaki head. Somewhat spicy, sweet toasted cracker, light citrus, a bit grainy aroma. Dried orange, somewhat fruity but dry flavor with a very nice toasted husky taste. Nice stuff and worth seeking out.

Tap at Churchkey - nonic pint glass. Poured a slightly creamy golden color with a thick white head. Aroma was crisp fruits, grain notes were very present in this one. Pretty refreshing - fruit notes, some grain.
Exclusive to St. Louis Pi pizza parlors, this is a "steam" style ale like Anchor. Dark, golden hue, but thin and dry. Not bad at all.
Dark translucent red.  Fizzy.  Very good.  Unique.  Low ibu.  Thin head.  Malty but medium body.

Tap. Pours clear amber with thin, creamy off-white; short retention and some lacing. Aroma is toasted and caramel malts, grassy hops, light yeast, and light spice. Flavor is balanced malts and hops with faint fruit esters; dry finish. Medium body and carbonation with low warmth.

Tasted on tap at Pi restaurant in Kirkwood, Missouri, USA into shaker. Poured a nice, clear orangish-copper color with fluffy white foam which subsided to a persistent layer of bubbles and lots of lace. Brewed in the California Common style, one of the only true American originals, a historical technique to emulate popular lagers in warmer ambient California temperatures, typified by Anchor Steam of San Francisco. Spicier hops than I expected, and in interesting ways: mint, cedar and licorice-root from the Marynka and piney citrus rind of Chinook. Great well-rounded mouthfeel, even a hint of rye-like sharpness. Overall, an excellent true-to-style recipe. As delicious and complex as Anchor Steam, which is saying A LOT, albeit in slightly different ways. Anyone who expects more from this beer really doesnt understand the style. I also like the double meaning of "Common," keeping with Pis mathematics theme. I dont care what anyone says: all things considered, this is another "uncommonly" tasty Schlafly brew. The ultimate pizza beer, which was the whole point. Recommended.

On tap at Pi in Dc. Served in a nonic pint glass.

Pours a moderate golden color with a good white head and a bit of lacing on the way down. The nose carries some light grain and perhaps a touch of fruit. Flavor is likewise pretty tame without very much going on. Light-medium body with good carbonation and a semi-dry finish, though the body is just a bit chewy. Average.
Draft at Pi.  Light amber color, small white head, solid lacing.  Aroma of rye bread, sesame seed.  Taste is dry soda bread, caramel, bitter finish.  OK.

Draft at Churchkey. Amber pour. Leafy hop and light toffee caramel mark this beer on the palate. The flavor brings more nice balance between west coast hop presence and light nutty malt, with a touch of strawberry fruitness. Solid.

Had on draft at 33. Pours copper with an off white head. Aroma is caramel malts, a bit of floral hops and nuts. Flavor is bread, toasted malts, yeast and a bit of hops. Light bodied with medium carbonation. pretty good finish as well.

Tasted 10/2/10. Pint from the Pi pizza on Delmar. Filtered with a copper hue. Moldy off-white head. Aromas of mild bread and faint esters. Medium bodied with a very bready palate. Good body and a rather straight up style. Rich with a medium roasted malt bill. Extremely dry finish. Solidly produced and flavorful!

Draft pint at Pi on Delmar.  Pours a mostly clear orange-gold color, a little too dull and browned to be called amber, with a small off-white head.  Aroma of caramel malts, toast, husk, nuts, and just a bit of earthy, floral hops.  Flavor of toasty caramel malts, nuts, earthy hops, bread, yeast, and a little tangerine citrus.  Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation and a dry, malty mouthfeel.  Nice take on a style I havent really tried much, save for Anchor Steam.  I liked this one a bit better, though.

Pours copper / brown with a small off-white head.  The aroma has toasty malt, dry caramel and an overall smoothness.  Medium body with mild carbonation.  The taste is quite dry, bready and crackery with toasted malt, light spicy hops and some minerals.  The finish has more spicy hops and there is a lager like smoothness to the malt.  Nothing fancy, but a pretty nice beer.
(Draught Pi CWE) Gold/amber with white head. Mild biscuit aroma. Flavor is biscuit malt and slight grassy hops. Good cal common.

Draft.  Medium beige head atop clear amber body, nice lacing.  Aroma is medium sweet, lager yeast, some spicy, caramel/bread.  Taste is medium sweet, bread, spicy, grass/straw, some lemon lagery, caramel.  Fairly smooth light-medium body.
